doc.abstracts: The document summarizes the findings of a survey undertaken among 1080 children, attending 5th and 6th grade in the rural schools of Bolivia Altiplano. The findings of the survey indicate low penetration of local production in current school feeding programs in the areas covered by the survey; compliance with current sanitary standards, availability of products, as well as poor knowledge by local suppliers of public procurement processes, are major factors limiting local purchases. In 37 percent of the schools, there is not a school menu; the purchasing decisions are largely being made by school committees and/or the municipalities. Therefore, nutritional educational programs should largely target these groups. Perceptions on the importance of nutritional considerations as guiding purchasing decisions is very high, but in practice, only 64 percent of the municipalities prioritize this criteria at the moment of purchasing products. Results of the diversity score suggest a diverse diet; therefore other factors such as the amount consumed rather than food diversity might be influencing nutritional problems in the Altiplano. Perceptions and preferences by children on the selected five Andean products are not a barrier to consumption. Overall, the survey highlights important opportunities for improving consumption of the five Andean products, through nutritional education and strengthening links between local production and School Feeding Programs. The survey was coordinated by the World Bank, with technical support by FAO nutrition and statistical departments, and implemented with funds from the SecureNutrition Knowledge Platform. Implementation in the field was led by PROINPA and the Bolivian Private University.
